comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: 1926 to 1949 is???  The tractor would have been a major investment and would have been expected to last for years so it could have been taken any time after 1921!  The baskets could have been for seedlings which would have needed some protection against crushing, drying and so on.  Looking at the bags they appear to be lumpy in the way that branches would affect them?  The young lady is very pretty and as you said very well dressed for the occasion, she was probably one of the Powers and not a field hand in the making!

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Tobacco? Hamburg was the center of the German cigar making industry. William Power & Co. was a large tobacco grower.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You're quite right, as always! :)  I should have been more specific. Definitely think that as the tractor registration (YI 9417) is almost at the top end of the numbering, that it must have been bought and registered very close  to the cut-off point for that sequence - YI 9999 was in March 1927 - hence this photo must have been taken after 1926.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Well now, tobacco. You could be spot on...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
This is a big help to narrow the dating. Definitely 1926 or later. At this point the company was still called William Power & Sons. The name changed to William Power & Co. in 1942, when William senior died, and William junior took over.
So, some time between 1926 and 1942! Wonder if we can do better than that even...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Did Ireland still trade with Germany during the war years? If not, the latest date was before the winter of 1939.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] Good thinking! So now, we're down to between 1926-1939...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
